messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Many-valued Argumentation, Conditionals and a Probabilistic Semantics for Gradual Argumentation

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
The strong relations between the notions of coherent, faithfull and Ï†ğœ‘\varphi-coherent labellings of a gradual argumentation graph and the
corresponding semantics of weighted conditional knowledge bases have suggested
an approach for defeasible reasoning over a weighted argumentation graph  2, which builds on the semantics of the argumentation graph. Given an argumentation graph GğºG and a gradual argumentation semantics Sğ‘†S,
we define a preferential (many-valued) interpretation of the argumentation graph GğºG, with respect to the gradual semantics Sğ‘†S.
In the following, we first consider a propositional language to represent boolean combination of arguments and a many-valued semantics for it on the domain of argument valuation. Then, we extend the language with a typicality operator, to introduce defeasible implications over boolean combinations of arguments and define a (multi-)preferential interpretation associated with the argumentation graph GğºG and the argumentation semantics Sğ‘†S.
A similar extension with typicality of a propositional language has, for instance, been considered for the two-valued case in the Propositional Typicality Logic . Let us consider an argumentation graph G=âŸ¨ğ’œ,â„›,Ï€âŸ©ğºğ’œâ„›ğœ‹G=\langle\mathcal{A},\mathcal{R},\pi\rangle, which may be weighted or not, and some gradual argumentation semantics Sğ‘†S for GğºG. In case the graph is not weighted, we let Ï€â€‹(B,A)=âˆ’1ğœ‹ğµğ´1\pi(B,A)=-1 mean that argument BğµB attacks argument Ağ´A, and Ï€â€‹(B,A)=+1ğœ‹ğµğ´1\pi(B,A)=+1 mean that argument BğµB supports argument Ağ´A.
We refer to  for a classification and the properties of gradual semantics when the argumentation graph is not weighted. We introduce a propositional language â„’â„’\mathcal{L}, whose set of propositional variables Pâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹pğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘Prop is the set of arguments ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}.
Assume our language â„’â„’\mathcal{L} contains the connectives âˆ§\wedge, âˆ¨\vee, Â¬\neg and â†’â†’\rightarrow, and that propositional formulas are defined inductively from the set of propositional variables, as usual. Propositional formulas, when restricted to the propositional variables in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, correspond to boolean combination of arguments, which have been considered, for instance, by Hunter et al. . We will use Î±,Î²,Î³ğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾\alpha,\beta,\gamma to denote boolean combination of arguments. Let ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} be a truth degree set, equipped with a preorder relation â‰¤\leq.
This choice for the domain of argument valuations has been proposed by Baroni et al.  as it is general enough to include the domain of argument valuations in most gradual argumentation semantics.
Let the truth set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} be the domain of argument valuation of a gradual semantics Sğ‘†S for the argumentation graph GğºG.
We let âŠ—tensor-product\otimes, âŠ•direct-sum\oplus, âŠ³contains-as-subgroup\rhd and âŠ–symmetric-difference\ominus be
the truth degree functions in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} for the connectives âˆ§\wedge, âˆ¨\vee, Â¬\neg and â†’â†’\rightarrow (respectively).
For instance, when ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} is [ref]0 [ref]0  or the finite set ğ’nsubscriptğ’ğ‘›\mathcal{C}_{n}, âŠ—tensor-product\otimes, âŠ•direct-sum\oplus, âŠ³contains-as-subgroup\rhd and âŠ–symmetric-difference\ominus can be chosed as a t-norm, s-norm, implication function, and negation function in some well known system of many-valued logic . A labelling Ïƒ:ğ’œâ†’ğ’®:ğœâ†’ğ’œğ’®\sigma:\mathcal{A}\rightarrow\mathcal{S} assigns to each argument Aiâˆˆğ’œsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ’œA_{i}\in\mathcal{A} a truth degree in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}, that is,

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Ïƒâ€‹(Î±âˆ¨Î²)=Ïƒâ€‹(Î±)âŠ•Ïƒâ€‹(Î²)ğœğ›¼ğ›½direct-sumğœğ›¼ğœğ›½\sigma(\alpha\vee\beta)=\sigma(\alpha)\oplus\sigma(\beta) Ïƒâ€‹(Î±â†’Î²)=Ïƒâ€‹(Î±)âŠ³Ïƒâ€‹(Î²)ğœâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½contains-as-subgroupğœğ›¼ğœğ›½\sigma(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)=\sigma(\alpha)\rhd\sigma(\beta)
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Ïƒâ€‹(Â¬Î±)=âŠ–Ïƒâ€‹(Î±)ğœğ›¼symmetric-differenceğœğ›¼\sigma(\neg\alpha)=\ominus\sigma(\alpha) Based on the choice of the combination functions, a labelling Ïƒğœ\sigma uniquely assigns a truth degree to any boolean combination of arguments. In the following we will assume that the false argument âŠ¥bottom\bot and the true argument âŠ¤top\top are formulas of Lğ¿L and that Ïƒâ€‹(âŠ¥)=0ğœbottom0\sigma(\bot)=0 and Ïƒâ€‹(âŠ¤)=1ğœtop1\sigma(\top)=1, for all labellings Ïƒğœ\sigma. Let Î£Î£\Sigma be a set of labellings of a weighted argumentation graph G=âŸ¨ğ’œ,â„›,Ï€âŸ©ğºğ’œâ„›ğœ‹G=\langle\mathcal{A},\mathcal{R},\pi\rangle, e.g., the labellings of GğºG under a given gradual semantics Sğ‘†S with domain of argument valuation ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}.
As an example, Î£Î£\Sigma may be the set of the finitely-valued Ï†ğœ‘\varphi-coherent labellings of the graph GğºG with values in ğ’nsubscriptğ’ğ‘›\mathcal{C}_{n}. Given a set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma, for each argument Aiâˆˆğ’œsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ’œA_{i}\in\mathcal{A} , we can define a preference relation <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} on Î£Î£\Sigma, as follows: where << is the strict partial order on ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} defined from the preorder â‰¤\leq as usual
(a<bâ€‹Â iffÂ â€‹aâ‰¤bâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹bâ‰°ağ‘ğ‘Â iffÂ ğ‘ğ‘Â andÂ ğ‘not-less-than-or-equalsğ‘a<b\mbox{ iff }a\leq b\mbox{ and }b\not\leq a).
The labelling Ïƒğœ\sigma is preferred to labelling Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} with respect to argument Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} (or Ïƒğœ\sigma is more plausible than Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} for argument Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}), when the degree of truth of Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} in Ïƒğœ\sigma is greater than the degree of truth of Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} in Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime}.
The preference relation <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is a strict partial order relation on Î£Î£\Sigma.
When â‰¤\leq is a total preorder on ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S},
<Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is also modular, that is, for all Ïƒâ€²,Ïƒâ€²â€²,Ïƒâ€²â€²â€²âˆˆÎ£superscriptğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²â€²Î£\sigma^{\prime},\sigma^{\prime\prime},\sigma^{\prime\prime\prime}\in\Sigma, Ïƒâ€²<AiÏƒâ€²â€²subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–superscriptğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²\sigma^{\prime}<_{A_{i}}\sigma^{\prime\prime} implies (Ïƒâ€²<AiÏƒâ€²â€²â€²subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–superscriptğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²â€²\sigma^{\prime}<_{A_{i}}\sigma^{\prime\prime\prime} or Ïƒâ€²â€²â€²<AiÏƒâ€²â€²subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–superscriptğœâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğœâ€²â€²\sigma^{\prime\prime\prime}<_{A_{i}}\sigma^{\prime\prime}).
For instance, when ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} is equal to [ref]0 [ref]0  or to ğ’nsubscriptğ’ğ‘›\mathcal{C}_{n}, <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is a strict modular partial order relation. When the set Î£Î£\Sigma is infinite, <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is not guaranteed to be well-founded, as there may be infinitely-descending chains of labellings
Ïƒ2<AiÏƒ1subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğœ2subscriptğœ1\sigma_{2}<_{A_{i}}\sigma_{1},
Ïƒ3<AiÏƒ2subscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğœ3subscriptğœ2\sigma_{3}<_{A_{i}}\sigma_{2}, â€¦â€¦\ldots.
In the following, we will restrict our consideration to sets of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma such that <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is well-founded for all arguments Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} in Î£Î£\Sigma. We will call Î£Î£\Sigma a well-founded set of labellings. The definition of preference over arguments which is induced by a set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma also extends to boolean combination of arguments Î±ğ›¼\alpha in the obvious way,
given a choice of combination functions. A set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma induces a preference relation <Î±subscriptğ›¼<_{\alpha} on Î£Î£\Sigma, for each boolean combination of arguments Î±ğ›¼\alpha, as follows: Ïƒ<Î±Ïƒâ€²â€‹Â iffÂ â€‹Ïƒâ€²â€‹(Î±)<Ïƒâ€‹(Î±)subscriptğ›¼ğœsuperscriptğœâ€²Â iffÂ superscriptğœâ€²ğ›¼ğœğ›¼\sigma<_{\alpha}\sigma^{\prime}\mbox{ iff }\sigma^{\prime}(\alpha)<\sigma(\alpha).
Note that if <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} is well-founded for all arguments Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} in Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime}, it is well-founded for all boolean combination of arguments Î±ğ›¼\alpha. We now define a notion of preferential interpretation over many-valued valuations, which relates to preferential interpretations in KLM preferential logics and, when preferences <Aisubscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘–<_{A_{i}} are modular, to ranked interpretations .
As seen above, here preferences are defined over many-valued labellings, rather than over two-valued propositional valuations.
A further difference with KLM approach is that the semantics exploits multiple preferences (one for each argument) rather than a single one, being then a multi-preferential semantics. Some multi-preferential semantics for KLM conditional logics have been considered in 1 ,
and, for ranked and weighted knowledge bases in fuzzy description logics in 5.  Given an argumentation graph G=âŸ¨ğ’œ,G=\langle\mathcal{A}, â„›,Ï€âŸ©\mathcal{R},\pi\rangle,
and Î£Î£\Sigma a set of labellings of GğºG, in some gradual semantics of GğºG with the domain of argument valuation ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S},
a preferential interpretation of GğºG wrt. Î£Î£\Sigma, is a pair I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma),
where Î£Î£\Sigma is a set of labellings Ïƒ:ğ’œâ†’ğ’®:ğœâ†’ğ’œğ’®\sigma:\mathcal{A}\rightarrow\mathcal{S}. Note that preference relations <Î±subscriptğ›¼<_{\alpha} in Iğ¼I are left implicit, as they are induced by the set of labellings in Î£Î£\Sigma. A unary typicality operator ğ“ğ“{\bf T} can be added to the language Lğ¿L. We will call the extended language Lğ“superscriptğ¿ğ“L^{\bf T}, and the associated many-valued logic with typicality â„’ğ“superscriptâ„’ğ“\mathcal{L}^{\bf T}.
Intuitively, as in the Propositional Typicality Logic, â€œa sentence of the form ğ“â€‹(Î±)ğ“ğ›¼{\bf T}(\alpha) is understood to refer to the typical situations in which Î±ğ›¼\alpha holdsâ€ . The typicality operator allows the formulation of conditional implications (or defeasible implications) of the form ğ“â€‹(Î±)â†’Î²â†’ğ“ğ›¼ğ›½{\bf T}(\alpha)\rightarrow\beta, whose meaning is that â€normally, if Î±ğ›¼\alpha then Î²ğ›½\betaâ€, where Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are boolean combination of arguments. In the two-valued case such implications correspond to conditional implications Î±âˆ£âˆ¼Î²\alpha\mathrel{{\scriptstyle\mid\!\sim}}\beta of KLM preferential logics .
As usual , we do not allow nesting of the typicality operator.
When Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta do not contain occurrences of the typicality operator, an implication Î±â†’Î²â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\beta is called strict.
In the following, we do not restrict our consideration to strict or defeasible implications, but we allow in the language Lğ“superscriptğ¿ğ“L^{\bf T} general implications of the form Î±â†’Î²â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\beta, where Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are boolean combination of arguments which may contain (unnested) occurrences of the typicality operator. The interpretation of a typicality formula ğ“â€‹(Î±)ğ“ğ›¼{\bf T}(\alpha) is defined with respect to a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma).
We define the truth degree of a typicality formula ğ“â€‹(Î±)ğ“ğ›¼{\bf T}(\alpha) in a valuation ÏƒâˆˆÎ£ğœÎ£\sigma\in\Sigma of the preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma) taking into account all labellings in Î£Î£\Sigma.
In the next definition we are assuming the set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma to be well-founded. Given a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma), and a labelling ÏƒâˆˆÎ£ğœÎ£\sigma\in\Sigma, the valuation of a propositional formula ğ“â€‹(Î±)ğ“ğ›¼{\bf T}(\alpha) in Ïƒğœ\sigma is defined as follows: where min<Î±(Î£)={Ïƒ:ÏƒâˆˆÎ£min_{<_{\alpha}}(\Sigma)=\{\sigma:\sigma\in\Sigma and âˆ„â€‹Ïƒâ€²âˆˆÎ£not-existssuperscriptğœâ€²Î£\nexists\sigma^{\prime}\in\Sigma s.t. Ïƒâ€²<Î±Ïƒ}\sigma^{\prime}<_{\alpha}\sigma\}. The truth value of ğ“â€‹(Î±)ğ“ğ›¼{\bf T}(\alpha) in ÏƒâˆˆÎ£ğœÎ£\sigma\in\Sigma depends on the whole set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma in the preferential interpretation Iğ¼I.
When (ğ“â€‹(A))Iâ€‹(Ïƒ)>0superscriptğ“ğ´ğ¼ğœ0({\bf T}(A))^{I}(\sigma)>0, Ïƒğœ\sigma is a labelling assigning a maximal degree of acceptability to argument Ağ´A in Iğ¼I.
i.e., it is a labelling maximizing the acceptability of argument Ağ´A, among all the labellings in Iğ¼I.
Similarly, in Propositional Typicality Logic , the evaluation of a typicality formula in a preferential interpretation depends on the set of all propositional valuations in the interpretation. Observe that, with the definition above, we are departing from previous semantics of typicality in the fuzzy and many-valued description logics 5 , as we are not defining a two-valued interpretation for ğ“â€‹(A)ğ“ğ´{\bf T}(A). The typicality operator is not simply intended to single out those labellings ÏƒâˆˆÎ£ğœÎ£\sigma\in\Sigma which maximize the acceptability degree of argument Ağ´A, but it assigns a truth degree to ğ“â€‹(A)ğ“ğ´{\bf T}(A) in Ïƒğœ\sigma which may be different from 00 or 111. Given a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma), where the labellings in Î£Î£\Sigma have domain of argument valuation ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} we can now define the satisfiability in Iğ¼I of a graded implication, having the form Î±â†’Î²â‰¥lâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘™\alpha\rightarrow\beta\geq l or Î±â†’Î²â‰¤uâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘¢\alpha\rightarrow\beta\leq u, for lğ‘™l and uğ‘¢u values in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}.
We first define the truth degree of an implication Î±â†’Î²â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\beta wrt. a preferential interpretation Iğ¼I. Given a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma) associated with an argumentation graph GğºG,
the truth degree of an implication Î±â†’Î²â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\beta wrt. Iğ¼I is defined as follows: (Î±â†’Î²)I=iâ€‹nâ€‹fÏƒâˆˆÎ£â€‹(Ïƒâ€‹(Î±)âŠ³Ïƒâ€‹(Î²))superscriptâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğœÎ£contains-as-subgroupğœğ›¼ğœğ›½(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)^{I}=inf_{\sigma\in\Sigma}(\sigma(\alpha)\rhd\sigma(\beta)) As a special case, for defeasible implications, we have that: (ğ“â€‹(Î±)â†’Î²)I=iâ€‹nâ€‹fÏƒâˆˆÎ£â€‹(Ïƒâ€‹(ğ“â€‹(Î±))âŠ³Ïƒâ€‹(Î²))superscriptâ†’ğ“ğ›¼ğ›½ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğœÎ£contains-as-subgroupğœğ“ğ›¼ğœğ›½({\bf T}(\alpha)\rightarrow\beta)^{I}=inf_{\sigma\in\Sigma}(\sigma({\bf T}(\alpha))\rhd\sigma(\beta)) meaning that in the most typical situations (labellings) in which Î±ğ›¼\alpha holds, Î²ğ›½\beta also holds.
Note that the interpretation of an implication (and of a defeasible implication) is defined globally wrt. a preferential interpretation Iğ¼I, and it is based on the whole set of labellings Î£Î£\Sigma in I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma). This is similar to the interpretation of conditionals Aâˆ£âˆ¼BA\mathrel{{\scriptstyle\mid\!\sim}}B in a preferential model in KLM preferential semantics  , as the semantics of conditional formulas depends (globally) on the set of propositional valuations in the preferential model as well as on the preference relation. We can now define the satisfiability of a graded implication in a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma). Given a preferential interpretation I=(ğ’®,Î£)ğ¼ğ’®Î£I=(\mathcal{S},\Sigma) of an argumentation graph GğºG,
Iğ¼I satisfies a graded implication Î±â†’Î²â‰¥lâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘™\alpha\rightarrow\beta\geq l (written IâŠ§Î±â†’Î²â‰¥lmodelsğ¼ğ›¼â†’ğ›½ğ‘™I\models\alpha\rightarrow\beta\geq l) iff (Î±â†’Î²)Iâ‰¥lsuperscriptâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ¼ğ‘™(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)^{I}\geq l;
Iğ¼I satisfies a graded implication Î±â†’Î²â‰¤uâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘¢\alpha\rightarrow\beta\leq u (written IâŠ§Î±â†’Î²â‰¤umodelsğ¼ğ›¼â†’ğ›½ğ‘¢I\models\alpha\rightarrow\beta\leq u) iff (Î±â†’Î²)Iâ‰¤usuperscriptâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ¼ğ‘¢(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)^{I}\leq u. Notice that the valuation of a graded implication (e.g., Î±â†’Î²â‰¥lâ†’ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘™\alpha\rightarrow\beta\geq l) in a preferential interpretation Iğ¼I is two-valued (that is, either the graded implication is satisfied in Iğ¼I (i.e., IâŠ§Î±â†’Î²â‰¥lmodelsğ¼ğ›¼â†’ğ›½ğ‘™I\models\alpha\rightarrow\beta\geq l) or it is not (i.e.,

Hence, it is natural to consider boolean combinations of graded implications, such as the following ones: (ğ“(A1)â†’A2âˆ§A3â‰¤0.3)âˆ§(ğ“(A3âˆ¨A1)â†’A4)â‰¥0.6)({\bf T}(A_{1})\rightarrow A_{2}\wedge A_{3}\leq 0.3)\wedge({\bf T}(A_{3}\vee A_{1})\rightarrow A_{4})\geq 0.6), and (ğ“(A1)â†’A2âˆ§A3â‰¤0.3)â†’(ğ“(A1)â†’A4)â‰¥0.6)({\bf T}(A_{1})\rightarrow A_{2}\wedge A_{3}\leq 0.3)\rightarrow({\bf T}(A_{1})\rightarrow A_{4})\geq 0.6), and define their satisfiability in an interpretation Iğ¼I in the obvious way, based on the semantics of classical propositional logic.
